title: 110_s3701
content: The Act may be cited as the "Best Buddies Empowerment for People with Intellectual Disabilities Act of 2008". Best Buddies is the first national social and recreational program in the US for individuals with intellectual disabilities. It aims to integrate them into mainstream society, end social isolation, and enhance their self-esteem through friendships and employment opportunities since 1989. Best Buddies is an international organization with programs in middle schools, high schools, and colleges that create 1-to-1 friendships between students with intellectual disabilities and their peers. They aim to positively impact over 350,000 individuals in 2008 and 500,000 by 2010. The Best Buddies organization facilitates friendships between individuals with and without intellectual disabilities through various programs like e-Buddies, Citizens, and Jobs. The purpose of the Act is to support Best Buddies in increasing participation, raising awareness, dispelling stereotypes, and highlighting the talents of people with intellectual disabilities. The Act aims to provide assistance for Best Buddies in increasing participation, raising awareness, dispelling stereotypes, and highlighting the talents of people with intellectual disabilities. The Act allows the Secretary of Education to provide grants to Best Buddies for activities promoting the expansion of social relationships and community participation for individuals with intellectual disabilities in the U.S. Funding cannot be used for medical treatment, and administrative expenses are limited to 5%. Non-Federal funds can also be used by Best Buddies. SEC. 4. APPLICATION AND ANNUAL REPORT. To be eligible for funding, Best Buddies must submit an application with a description of activities and specific goals. They must also agree to submit an annual report to receive funds. Best Buddies must agree to submit an annual report with specific information as required by the Secretary of Education. The report should detail progress towards meeting goals outlined in their application. Authorization of appropriations for grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements under section 3(a) is set at $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, with additional funding as needed for the following 4 years.
